Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ends of Oil: Changing Life in Earth Science, Extractive Industry and Indigenous Communities in Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
How does oil as a resource and social and economic force end? And what comes next? In Alaska, these are some of the most pressing questions for northern communities facing dwindling dividends, aging pipelines, and eroding coastlines. This exploratory research project will examine how a variety of stakeholders - earth scientists, oil companies, state policy-makers, and Alaska Native peoples - are each responding to the fiscal, infrastructural, environmental, and cosmological ends of oil in Alaska and envisioning how life might carry on afterwards.

The aim of this proposed EAGER research is to make contact with these stakeholders, survey their engagements with the issue, visit field sites, and identify partners in order to better craft a collaborative, multi-sited research project on the ends of oil in northern Alaska. EAGER support will enable this exploratory research to incorporate local concerns into the design and implementation of a larger research project on "the Ends of Oil in Alaska."

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whether in dwindling dividends, aging pipelines, eroding coastlines, or new exploration projects, northern Alaska offers a compelling vantage point for understanding the social implications of energy development, environmental change and wellbeing today.  

The purpose of this EAGER research was to initiate dialogue with rural Alaskan communities on how they are navigating the economic, social and environmental instabilities of oil, and to advance local insights on these questions into wider policy and scholarly projects. To do so, PI Lucas Bessire (University of Oklahoma) traveled to communities in northern Alaska with PI David Bond (Bennington College) and: 1) met with a variety of stakeholders, from earth scientists to oil company representatives, from state policy-makers to Indigenous leaders; 2) surveyed local engagements with energy use and development, including the costs of gasoline and heating oil, the migration patterns of keystone species, the Arctic monitoring of planetary CO2 emissions, and the projected impacts of proposed development projects; 3) consulted with communities to develop and field-test experimental methods to conduct social research in collaboration with local communities, initiative and experts; and 4) identified Alaskan institutions and partners for future research projects on these and other related themes. Together, these preliminary findings allowed us to foreground local concerns and capacities within the design of a larger collaborative research proposal on energy, environment and wellbeing in a changing Alaska. 

 

PI Bessire traveled to major cities in Alaska and a number of rural communities in northern Alaska in August 2016 in order to meet with local leaders and residents, and to explore the possibility of collaborating on research in the near future. Communities visited include: Anaktuvak Pass, Anchorage, Barrow, Fairbanks, Kaktovik, and Wainwright. We also visited a number of earth science experiments underway in Barrow and Kaktovik to learn more about how the Arctic offers a compelling lens from which to examine planetary change and social futures. Lastly, we met with a number off federal, state, municipal, and non-governmental agencies working on related topics to learn from their expertise and to explore potential partnerships on future research, including: the Alaska Native Studies and Rural Development Department at UAF, the Center for Alaska Native Health Research at UAF, Cold Climate Housing Center, First Alaskans Institute, the Global Monitoring Division of NOAA, the North Slope Borough Department of Wildlife Management, UIC Science, and US Fish and Wildlife Service.

 

Planned presentations and publications that result from this research offer preliminary reflections and initial framings on a range of topics, from the experienced convergence of economic and environmental instabilities of oil in Alaska today to the rising storylines of changing life in the Arctic to the critical import of collaborative methods and community driven research. 

 

This was an exploratory research project aimed at organizing a more effective theoretical and methodological foundation for future collaborative research around urgent questions with regional and planetary implications. Within that frame, the preliminary findings from the early-stage research are as follows: 1) the proactive involvement of local, community and regional organizations in shaping environmental futures; 2) the contemporary genre of change in the North and the changing significance of the Arctic for global audiences; 3) the inputs of local communities for a variety analytical and industrial projects in the North and the resulting presence of research within many communities in northern Alaska; and, 4) the practical and theoretical purchase of collaborative methods in social science research today.
